title: How to Grill Turkey Breast

steps.headline: Combine water, salt, and sugar in a large container.
steps.description: Grab a container large enough to hold the turkey breast and water. Add the ice cold water, then stir in the salt and sugar until they're fully dissolved. Brining is an optional step. You can skip it if you don't have time, but it'll add flavor and keep your turkey breast from drying out on the grill. If you aren't brining the breast, you should still rinse it and pat it dry.

steps.headline: Submerge the breast in the brine, then refrigerate it overnight.
steps.description: Place the turkey in the brine, cover the container, then place it in the refrigerator. Brine the breast in the fridge for 8 to 12 hours. If you don't have time to brine the breast overnight, brining it for about an hour will still lend some moisture.

steps.headline: Rinse the breast thoroughly.
steps.description: Remove the turkey from the brine, then rinse it with cool water. The salt and sugar already soaked into the meat, so don't worry about washing them away.

steps.headline: Pat the turkey breast dry with paper towels.
steps.description: Thoroughly drying the breast is a key step. Excess moisture will leave your final product with soggy skin that sticks to your grill's cooking grates. When working with raw meat, remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water before touching other objects or surfaces.

steps.headline: Soak apple or cherry wood chips in water for 30 minutes (optional).
steps.description: Wood chips will add nice, smokey flavor to your turkey. If you decide to use them, submerge 4 to 8 ounces (110 to 230 g) of wood chips in a bowl of water before you season the breast. That way, they'll have time to soak while you prep.

steps.headline: Combine softened butter, chopped herbs, lemon zest, and orange zest.
steps.description: Add your seasonings to a medium mixing bowl and stir them until they're well combined. For the chopped herbs, use your choice of fresh rosemary or thyme.

steps.headline: Loosen the skin and rub half of the butter mixture all over the breast.
steps.description: Use your fingers to carefully loosen a section of skin from the breast so you can access the flesh beneath it. Rub half of your butter mixture under the skin and all over the outside of the breast. Reserve half of the butter mixture to use later.

steps.headline: Set your gas grill to medium-high heat or light your charcoal grill.
steps.description: If you have a gas grill, set the burners to medium-high. If you have a charcoal grill, the best lighting method is to use a chimney starter. Using lighter fluid to ignite your charcoals will affect your turkey's taste.

steps.headline: Preheat your grill for 5 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Close the lid and allow your grill to preheat. If you have a charcoal grill, let it preheat for 5 minutes. If you have a gas grill, preheat it for 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Create a double-bank fire if you're using a charcoal grill.
steps.description: To make a double-bank fire, move the charcoals to either side of the firebox to leave room in the middle for a drip pan. Move the charcoals after they've turned ashy and the grill has come to temperature. A good grill has a hinged cooking grate. Instead of removing it completely, you can just lift a hinged grate to move charcoals or insert a drip pan. Whether you have to lift your grate or take it off of the grill completely, be careful not to burn yourself. Use tongs and insulated cooking gloves to prevent burns.

steps.headline: Place the drip pan under the cooking grate.
steps.description: You can use a large disposable foil pan to catch drippings or purchase a drip pan designed for your grill. If you have a charcoal grill and made a double-bank fire, place the pan between the charcoals. If you have a gas grill, place the drip pan under the cooking grate, then turn off the burners that sit under the drip pan. If your gas grill has a designated spot for a drip pan, place it there. Otherwise, place it over the center of the grill under the cooking grate. If you have a grill with a built-in drip pan, check it to make sure it's clean, as excess grease can cause flare-ups. Whether your grill is gas or charcoal, trim your foil pan's sides if it's too tall to fit between the bottom of the firebox and the cooking grate. Never use a drip pan to support the cooking grate.

steps.headline: Clean and oil the cooking grate.
steps.description: After the grill has come to temperature, scrub the grate with a long-handled wire grill brush. Then dip a wad of paper towels in vegetable oil, grab the wad with grill tongs, and lightly coat the grate with oil. Try to coat the grate as thinly and evenly as possible. Too much oil can cause a flare-up, and you don't want to char the breast.

steps.headline: Add the drained wood chips, if you're using them.
steps.description: You're just about ready to start grilling! Drain the wood chips, then lift the cooking grate and place them on the charcoal embers. Leave some room between the chips instead of completely covering the charcoals. If you have a gas grill, place the chips in an aluminum pan (or, if you have one, a pan made for wood chips), cover it with foil, and poke holes in the cover. Then lift the cooking grate and place the pan on the opposite side of the grill's air vent.

steps.headline: Melt the remaining butter mixture and add lemon and orange juice.
steps.description: Grab your reserved butter mixture and melt it in the microwave. If it's in a metal container, you can set it on the grill grate for a few seconds to melt the butter. Then add your citrus juices to the melted mixture.

steps.headline: Brush the mixture onto the turkey skin.
steps.description: Use a basting brush to coat the breast. Don't use it all; make sure you have enough to periodically baste the breast while it cooks.

steps.headline: Set the breast on the grate over the drip pan.
steps.description: Place the basted bird on the cooking grate skin side up, then lower the grill's lid. Make sure the breast sits over the drip pan you've set up in the center of the firebox. The turkey breast should stand skin side up without a problem. If it tilts over, use a roast holder to support it.

steps.headline: Grill the breast for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, and baste it every 20 minutes.
steps.description: Periodically brush a coat of the melted butter and citrus mixture over the turkey's skin. When the skin looks golden, insert a food thermometer into the thickest part of breast (without touching the bone). The turkey is done when its internal temperature reaches 165 °F (74 °C).

steps.headline: Rest the turkey for 15 to 20 minutes, then carve it and serve.
steps.description: Place the breast on a platter and let it rest uncovered. Carve it after 15 to 20 minutes and serve it with side dishes such as mashed potatoes, candied yams, and sauteed green beans.If you have leftovers, store them in the fridge for up to 4 days or freeze them for 4 to 6 months.

tyn: 4 to 8 ounces (110 to 230 g) Apple or cherry wood chips
Large foil pan (or built-in drip pan)
text: Brining Your Bird Combine water, salt, and sugar in a large container. Grab a container large enough to hold the turkey breast and water. Add the ice cold water, then stir in the salt and sugar until they're fully dissolved. Brining is an optional step. You can skip it if you don't have time, but it'll add flavor and keep your turkey breast from drying out on the grill. If you aren't brining the breast, you should still rinse it and pat it dry. Submerge the breast in the brine, then refrigerate it overnight. Place the turkey in the brine, cover the container, then place it in the refrigerator. Brine the breast in the fridge for 8 to 12 hours. If you don't have time to brine the breast overnight, brining it for about an hour will still lend some moisture. Rinse the breast thoroughly. Remove the turkey from the brine, then rinse it with cool water. The salt and sugar already soaked into the meat, so don't worry about washing them away. Pat the turkey breast dry with paper towels. Thoroughly drying the breast is a key step. Excess moisture will leave your final product with soggy skin that sticks to your grill's cooking grates. When working with raw meat, remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water before touching other objects or surfaces. Seasoning the Breast Soak apple or cherry wood chips in water for 30 minutes (optional). Wood chips will add nice, smokey flavor to your turkey. If you decide to use them, submerge 4 to 8 ounces (110 to 230 g) of wood chips in a bowl of water before you season the breast. That way, they'll have time to soak while you prep. Combine softened butter, chopped herbs, lemon zest, and orange zest. Add your seasonings to a medium mixing bowl and stir them until they're well combined. For the chopped herbs, use your choice of fresh rosemary or thyme. Loosen the skin and rub half of the butter mixture all over the breast. Use your fingers to carefully loosen a section of skin from the breast so you can access the flesh beneath it. Rub half of your butter mixture under the skin and all over the outside of the breast. Reserve half of the butter mixture to use later. Firing up the Grill Set your gas grill to medium-high heat or light your charcoal grill. If you have a gas grill, set the burners to medium-high. If you have a charcoal grill, the best lighting method is to use a chimney starter. Using lighter fluid to ignite your charcoals will affect your turkey's taste. Preheat your grill for 5 to 15 minutes. Close the lid and allow your grill to preheat. If you have a charcoal grill, let it preheat for 5 minutes. If you have a gas grill, preheat it for 15 minutes. Create a double-bank fire if you're using a charcoal grill. To make a double-bank fire, move the charcoals to either side of the firebox to leave room in the middle for a drip pan. Move the charcoals after they've turned ashy and the grill has come to temperature. A good grill has a hinged cooking grate. Instead of removing it completely, you can just lift a hinged grate to move charcoals or insert a drip pan. Whether you have to lift your grate or take it off of the grill completely, be careful not to burn yourself. Use tongs and insulated cooking gloves to prevent burns. Place the drip pan under the cooking grate. You can use a large disposable foil pan to catch drippings or purchase a drip pan designed for your grill. If you have a charcoal grill and made a double-bank fire, place the pan between the charcoals. If you have a gas grill, place the drip pan under the cooking grate, then turn off the burners that sit under the drip pan. If your gas grill has a designated spot for a drip pan, place it there. Otherwise, place it over the center of the grill under the cooking grate. If you have a grill with a built-in drip pan, check it to make sure it's clean, as excess grease can cause flare-ups. Whether your grill is gas or charcoal, trim your foil pan's sides if it's too tall to fit between the bottom of the firebox and the cooking grate. Never use a drip pan to support the cooking grate. Clean and oil the cooking grate. After the grill has come to temperature, scrub the grate with a long-handled wire grill brush. Then dip a wad of paper towels in vegetable oil, grab the wad with grill tongs, and lightly coat the grate with oil. Try to coat the grate as thinly and evenly as possible. Too much oil can cause a flare-up, and you don't want to char the breast. Add the drained wood chips, if you're using them. You're just about ready to start grilling! Drain the wood chips, then lift the cooking grate and place them on the charcoal embers. Leave some room between the chips instead of completely covering the charcoals. If you have a gas grill, place the chips in an aluminum pan (or, if you have one, a pan made for wood chips), cover it with foil, and poke holes in the cover. Then lift the cooking grate and place the pan on the opposite side of the grill's air vent. Grilling to Perfection Melt the remaining butter mixture and add lemon and orange juice. Grab your reserved butter mixture and melt it in the microwave. If it's in a metal container, you can set it on the grill grate for a few seconds to melt the butter. Then add your citrus juices to the melted mixture. Brush the mixture onto the turkey skin. Use a basting brush to coat the breast. Don't use it all; make sure you have enough to periodically baste the breast while it cooks. Set the breast on the grate over the drip pan. Place the basted bird on the cooking grate skin side up, then lower the grill's lid. Make sure the breast sits over the drip pan you've set up in the center of the firebox. The turkey breast should stand skin side up without a problem. If it tilts over, use a roast holder to support it. Grill the breast for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, and baste it every 20 minutes. Periodically brush a coat of the melted butter and citrus mixture over the turkey's skin. When the skin looks golden, insert a food thermometer into the thickest part of breast (without touching the bone). The turkey is done when its internal temperature reaches 165 °F (74 °C). Rest the turkey for 15 to 20 minutes, then carve it and serve. Place the breast on a platter and let it rest uncovered. Carve it after 15 to 20 minutes and serve it with side dishes such as mashed potatoes, candied yams, and sauteed green beans.If you have leftovers, store them in the fridge for up to 4 days or freeze them for 4 to 6 months.

Grab a container large enough to hold the turkey breast and water.
Add the ice cold water, then stir in the salt and sugar until they're fully dissolved.
Brining is an optional step.
You can skip it if you don't have time, but it'll add flavor and keep your turkey breast from drying out on the grill.
If you aren't brining the breast, you should still rinse it and pat it dry.
Submerge the breast in the brine, then refrigerate it overnight.

If you don't have time to brine the breast overnight, brining it for about an hour will still lend some moisture.

Remove the turkey from the brine, then rinse it with cool water.
The salt and sugar already soaked into the meat, so don't worry about washing them away.
Pat the turkey breast dry with paper towels.
Thoroughly drying the breast is a key step.
Excess moisture will leave your final product with soggy skin that sticks to your grill's cooking grates.
When working with raw meat, remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water before touching other objects or surfaces.
Seasoning the Breast Soak apple or cherry wood chips in water for 30 minutes (optional).
Wood chips will add nice, smokey flavor to your turkey.
If you decide to use them, submerge 4 to 8 ounces (110 to 230 g) of wood chips in a bowl of water before you season the breast.
That way, they'll have time to soak while you prep.
Combine softened butter, chopped herbs, lemon zest, and orange zest.
Add your seasonings to a medium mixing bowl and stir them until they're well combined.
For the chopped herbs, use your choice of fresh rosemary or thyme.
Loosen the skin and rub half of the butter mixture all over the breast.
Use your fingers to carefully loosen a section of skin from the breast so you can access the flesh beneath it.
Rub half of your butter mixture under the skin and all over the outside of the breast.
Reserve half of the butter mixture to use later.
Firing up the Grill Set your gas grill to medium-high heat or light your charcoal grill.
If you have a gas grill, set the burners to medium-high.
If you have a charcoal grill, the best lighting method is to use a chimney starter.
Using lighter fluid to ignite your charcoals will affect your turkey's taste.
Preheat your grill for 5 to 15 minutes.
Close the lid and allow your grill to preheat.
If you have a charcoal grill, let it preheat for 5 minutes.
If you have a gas grill, preheat it for 15 minutes.
Create a double-bank fire if you're using a charcoal grill.
To make a double-bank fire, move the charcoals to either side of the firebox to leave room in the middle for a drip pan.
Move the charcoals after they've turned ashy and the grill has come to temperature.
A good grill has a hinged cooking grate.
Instead of removing it completely, you can just lift a hinged grate to move charcoals or insert a drip pan.
Whether you have to lift your grate or take it off of the grill completely, be careful not to burn yourself.
Use tongs and insulated cooking gloves to prevent burns.
Place the drip pan under the cooking grate.
You can use a large disposable foil pan to catch drippings or purchase a drip pan designed for your grill.
If you have a charcoal grill and made a double-bank fire, place the pan between the charcoals.
If you have a gas grill, place the drip pan under the cooking grate, then turn off the burners that sit under the drip pan.
If your gas grill has a designated spot for a drip pan, place it there.
Otherwise, place it over the center of the grill under the cooking grate.
If you have a grill with a built-in drip pan, check it to make sure it's clean, as excess grease can cause flare-ups.
Whether your grill is gas or charcoal, trim your foil pan's sides if it's too tall to fit between the bottom of the firebox and the cooking grate.
Never use a drip pan to support the cooking grate.
Clean and oil the cooking grate.
After the grill has come to temperature, scrub the grate with a long-handled wire grill brush.
Then dip a wad of paper towels in vegetable oil, grab the wad with grill tongs, and lightly coat the grate with oil.
Try to coat the grate as thinly and evenly as possible.
Too much oil can cause a flare-up, and you don't want to char the breast.
Add the drained wood chips, if you're using them.
You're just about ready to start grilling!
Drain the wood chips, then lift the cooking grate and place them on the charcoal embers.
Leave some room between the chips instead of completely covering the charcoals.
If you have a gas grill, place the chips in an aluminum pan (or, if you have one, a pan made for wood chips), cover it with foil, and poke holes in the cover.
Then lift the cooking grate and place the pan on the opposite side of the grill's air vent.
Grilling to Perfection Melt the remaining butter mixture and add lemon and orange juice.
Grab your reserved butter mixture and melt it in the microwave.
If it's in a metal container, you can set it on the grill grate for a few seconds to melt the butter.
Then add your citrus juices to the melted mixture.
Brush the mixture onto the turkey skin.
Use a basting brush to coat the breast.
Don't use it all; make sure you have enough to periodically baste the breast while it cooks.
Set the breast on the grate over the drip pan.
Place the basted bird on the cooking grate skin side up, then lower the grill's lid.
Make sure the breast sits over the drip pan you've set up in the center of the firebox.
The turkey breast should stand skin side up without a problem.
If it tilts over, use a roast holder to support it.
Grill the breast for 1 to 1 1/2 hours, and baste it every 20 minutes.
Periodically brush a coat of the melted butter and citrus mixture over the turkey's skin.
When the skin looks golden, insert a food thermometer into the thickest part of breast (without touching the bone).
The turkey is done when its internal temperature reaches 165 °F (74 °C).
Rest the turkey for 15 to 20 minutes, then carve it and serve.
Place the breast on a platter and let it rest uncovered.

Carve it after 15 to 20 minutes and serve it with side dishes such as mashed potatoes, candied yams, and sauteed green beans.If you have leftovers, store them in the fridge for up to 4 days or freeze them for 4 to 6 months.
